item.title: Ticket #307 (Textile and Markdown in Upload template) created
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: Perhaps along with normal XHTML syntax, there could also be Markdown and Textile formatting for embedding an image?

item.title: Ticket #185 (wp-login.php segfaults Apache with PHP5.0.1-dev) updated
item.dc:creator: cvk
item.description:
Glad it's working for you now!

This is a problem with PHP 5.0.x, not with WordPress. The next stable release of PHP (5.1.x?) won't crash on conditional functions, according to this post in the PHP bugtracking system:

​http://bugs.php.net/bug.php?id=29944

For now, this workaround fits the bill, but I don't think it should become a part of the WordPress code since WordPress isn't broken.

Thanks, skithund, for discovering a fix.

item.title: Ticket #185 (wp-login.php segfaults Apache with PHP5.0.1-dev) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
@cvk

I see what you did now, thanks.. I actually pulled the case login as explained above. Well, I implemented those changes and what do you know.. it works.. it actually works.. ( at first glance ) Nice Troubleshooting!!!

Since I cannot seem to get any answers from WP forums on this might someone check this out:

​http://wordpress.org/support/3/13145 ​http://wordpress.org/support/3/13237

Seems as though no one has really come up with a solid answer as if this is a problem or... suggest a solution or some insight as to why it is happening. If there is a bug post somewhere here.. please let me know.

Kind regards, Gravity

item.title: Ticket #305 (Unable to create user with a particular username) created
item.dc:creator: pankajnarula
item.description:
I have been battling with the "mt import mixes authors" mentioned over here

​http://wordpress.org/support/3/7617

Today I started to resolve this again with the fresh nightly 09/19. While analying my fresh import I realized that import start misbehaving at a particular post and gives no username/author for that particular post. The author for that post was देबाशीष so I replaced every occurence of this with shorter देब. Import worked at that time. After the import I went into admin console so that I can change the username back to real longer one i.e. देबाशीष . Surprises of surprise I cann't create a user with the user name देबाशीष . Maybe this is the reason import was misbehaving. Anyone wants to take a look at this. Just copy the following text

देबाशीष

and try to create a user with this login name.

Also after I create the user, in the login name field it shows this

<code> देबाशीढ /></td> </tr> <tr> <th scope= </code>

I can give admin login access to the blog if you would email me at pankajnarula@…

item.title: Ticket #185 (wp-login.php segfaults Apache with PHP5.0.1-dev) updated
item.dc:creator: cvk
item.description:
There are two functions declared in a switch statement in wp-login.php. Moving those two function declarations out of the switch statement and to the top of the file (or bottom, or other places) will prevent the segfault for PHP 5.0.1.

(These line numbers refer to the nightly build in wordpress-2004-09-19.tar.gz. Yours might be on different lines.)

The first function, login(), is declared on lines 77-111.

The second, checklogin(), is declared on lines 243-253.

Those two chunks of code should be moved to the top of wp-login.php. I'll include my edited file for reference: wp-login.php, 10,877 bytes.

item.title: Ticket #185 (wp-login.php segfaults Apache with PHP5.0.1-dev) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
Seems as though there are more answers here then on WP itself. Any suggestions for IIS? What exactly was the change? I tried moving the login case section above the logout case section. Nothing changed. Can someone please provide more specific details for a tryable fix?

Kind regards, Gravity

edited on: 09-21-04 16:25

item.title: Ticket #185 (wp-login.php segfaults Apache with PHP5.0.1-dev) updated
item.dc:creator: cvk
item.description: I'm running wordpress-2004-09-14 on Apache 2.0.50/PHP 5.0.1/RHL9. I got the segfaults too, so I moved the login() and checklogin() function declarations to the top of wp-login.php as skithund suggested. All is well now; there are no segfaults anymore.

item.title: Ticket #304 (60+ databases errors (in syntax) in step 2 of install latest CVS) closed
item.dc:creator: dougal
item.description:
Not really a WP problem. The table prefix cannot contain a dash, unless the table names in the queries are quoted.

We probably *should* either error check the prefix for disallowed characters, or update all queries to quote table names.

item.title: Ticket #304 (60+ databases errors (in syntax) in step 2 of install latest CVS) updated
item.dc:creator: dougal
item.description:
I believe that the problem might be the use of a dash in your prefix. Try using 'wp_' instead of 'wp-'. From the MySQL docs:

<blockquote> An identifier may be quoted or unquoted. If an identifier is a reserved word or contains special characters, you must quote it whenever you refer to it. For a list of reserved words, see section 10.6 Treatment of Reserved Words in MySQL. Special characters are those outside the set of alphanumeric characters from the current character set, _', and $'. </blockquote>

item.title: Ticket #304 (60+ databases errors (in syntax) in step 2 of install latest CVS) updated
item.dc:creator: mark
item.description: Enter step 2 and 60+ databases errors (in syntax) are printed out. WordPress states it's finished but trying to log in is created with the "doesn't look like you have WordPress installed" screen.

item.title: Ticket #303 (Staticize Reloaded plugin causes problems with Gzip enabled) created
item.dc:creator: MC_incubus
item.description: I understand that Staticize Reloaded isn't meant to work with Gzip, but I think the plugin should check to see if Gzip is enabled, and disable it, if it is. A lot of people are just going to activate the plugin and be puzzled at the garbled output.
